{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox oil spill |spill_name = Montara oil spill |image = Oil Slick in the Timor Sea September-2009.jpg |image_size = 250px |image_caption = Satellite image of the [[oil slick]] in the Timor Sea, September 2009. |location = [[Timor Sea]], off the northern coast of [[Western Australia]] |spill_date = 21 August 2009 to 3 November 2009 (74 days) |cause = Leak from the Montara wellhead platform |operator = [[PTT Public Company Limited]] |volume={{convert|1.2|to|9|e6USgal|m3}} total |area = 6,000 km2 (2,300 sq mi) }}
The '''Montara oil spill''' was an [[sweet crude oil|oil]] and gas leak and subsequent slick that took place in the Montara oil field in the [[Timor Sea]], off the northern coast of [[Western Australia]]. It is considered one of Australia's worst [[oil spill|oil disasters]].<ref name=ABC2>{{cite news |title = WA oil spill 'one of Australia's worst' |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/08/24/2664927.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 24 August 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3RrgF24 |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> The slick was released following a blowout from the Montara wellhead platform on 21 August 2009, and continued leaking until 3 November 2009 (in total 74 days), when the leak was stopped by pumping [[Drilling fluid|mud]] into the well and the wellbore cemented thus "capping" the blowout.<ref name=ABCcap>{{cite news |title = West Atlas oil leak stopped |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/11/03/2732288.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 3 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3R9hPbY |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref><ref name=PTTEPpr87>{{cite press release |title = PTTEP Australasia Timor Sea Operations – Incident Information #87 |url = http://www.au.pttep.com/uploads/MediaRelease87_03-11-09.pdf |publisher = PTTEP Australasia |date = 3 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3MMzCW3 |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> The West Atlas rig is owned by the Norwegian-Bermudan [[Seadrill]], and operated by PTTEP Australasia (PTTEPAA), a subsidiary of [[PTT Exploration and Production]] (PTTEP) which is in turn a subsidiary of [[PTT Public Company Limited|PTT]], the Thai state-owned oil and gas company was operating over on adjacent well on the Montara platform. Houston-based [[Halliburton]] was involved in cementing the well.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/03/us/03montara.html|title=Relief Well Was Used to Halt Australian Spill|last=Bradsher|first=Keith|date=2 May 2010|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=29 July 2010}}</ref> The Montara field is located off the [[Kimberley (Western Australia)|Kimberley]] coast, {{convert|250|km|abbr=on}} north of [[Mungalalu Truscott Airbase|Truscott airbase]], and {{convert|690|km|abbr=on|-1}} west of [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]].<ref name=Buckeridge>{{cite news |title = Expert comment on West Atlas oil spill |first = John |last = Buckeridge |url = http://www.rmit.com.au/browse;ID=ekfgv9r1s8y61 |publisher = [[RMIT University|RMIT]] Newsroom |date = 24 August 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3T7EeGp |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref><ref name=ABC4>{{cite news |title = Rig still spilling oil off WA coast |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/08/21/2663426.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 21 August 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3RG8WjP |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref><ref name=ABC6>{{cite news |title = Timor Sea oil leak fix 'days away' |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/08/23/2663828.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 23 August 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3RNMS7o |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> Sixty-nine workers were safely evacuated from the West Atlas jackup drilling rig when the blowout occurred.<ref name=ABC4/><ref name="pttep1">(21 August 2009). [http://www.au.pttep.com/news/2009/august/information-release-statement-incident-information-4 Information Release Statement: Incident Information 4]. PTTEP Australasia. Retrieved 18 March 2012.</ref>
The Australian [[Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism]] estimated that the Montara oil leak could be as high as {{convert|2000|oilbbl|m3}}/day, five times the {{convert|400|oilbbl|m3}}/day estimated by PTTEP Australasia.<ref>{{cite news |title = Oil leaking 'five times faster' than thought |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/10/22/2721552.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 22 October 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3RU9Sv0 |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> A spokesman for Resources Minister, Martin Ferguson, said the {{convert|2000|oilbbl|m3}} referred to the amount of oil that the well could produce when brought into peak production.<ref name="oilleak">{{Cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2009-10-22/oil-leaking-five-times-faster-than-thought/1113420 |title=Oil leaking 'five times faster' than thought |accessdate=18 March 2012 |date=22 October 2009 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation }}</ref> After flying over the spill site, Australian Greens Senator [[Rachel Siewert]] claimed the spill was far greater than had originally been reported.<ref>{{cite web|first = Rachel |last = Siewert |authorlink = Rachel Siewert |title = WA oil spill much worse than thought |url = http://rachel-siewert.greensmps.org.au/content/wa-oil-spill-much-worse-thought |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3Ub2DTY |date = 29 August 2009 |archivedate = 5 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF-Australia]] also claimed that the spill was worse than originally expected.<ref name=WWF>{{cite news |title = Oil leak 'worse than feared' |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/10/23/2722164.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 23 October 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3RaQqtC |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref><ref name=WWF1>{{cite web|first = Simon |last = Mustoe |title = Biodiversity Survey of the Montara Field Oil Leak |url = http://www.wwf.org.au/publications/montaraoilspillreport.pdf |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3UASSlU |publisher = [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF-Australia]] |date = 22 October 2009 |archivedate = 5 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref>
The first four attempts to plug the oil leak by PTTEPAA failed, but the fifth attempt succeeded on 3 November 2009, when PTTEPAA pumped approximately {{convert|3400|oilbbl|m3}} of mud into a [[relief well]] to stop the leak.<ref name=ABCcap/><ref name=PTTEPpr87 /><ref name=plug1>{{cite news |title = Latest attempt fails to stop oil leak |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/10/17/2716879.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 17 October 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3RdcYHc |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref>
On 1 November 2009, during an attempt to stop the leak, a fire broke out on the West Atlas drilling rig.<ref name=BBCfire>{{cite news |title = Australia oil well catches fire |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8336564.stm |work = [[BBC News]] |date = 2 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3Uqeqsp |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> On 2 November, PTTEPAA said that the fire appeared to be burning off the oil and thereby preventing further leakage into the sea.<ref name=PTTEPpr86>{{cite press release |title = PTTEP Australasia Timor Sea Operations – Incident Information #86 |url = http://www.au.pttep.com/uploads/MediaRelease86_02-11-09.pdf |publisher = PTTEP Australasia |date = 2 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3JjXJ8C |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> The fire was largely extinguished when the leak was stopped.<ref name=ABCcap/><ref>{{cite news |title = Leaking oil rig continues to burn |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/11/01/2730073.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 1 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3Rjatdw |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> Once safety criteria were met, a specialist team boarded the Montara wellhead platform and the West Atlas to assess the damages.
The operation later in November 2009 to finally plug the well after the leak was stopped involved pumping a 1,400 metre cement plug from the West Triton rig down the relief well to the bottom of the 2.5 kilometre well. Once completed, the West Triton relief rig was demobilised and returned to Singapore.<ref>http://www.au.pttep.com/uploads/MediaRelease13_27-08-09.pdf</ref>
In December 2009, a team from PTTEPAA and Alert Well Control returned to the Montara field to complete the final stages of the operation, which involved inserting two mechanical barriers at depth above the cement plug into the well. Operations were completed in January 2010 when the reboarding team installed a capping assembly on the well.
Work to safely remove the West Atlas drilling rig from the Montara well head platform (WHP) in the Timor Sea started in August 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lloydslistdcn.com.au/archive/2010/september/15/west-atlas-rig-removal-begins|title=Lloyd's List Australia - Home|author=Lloyd's List Australia|publisher=|accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref>
The offshore construction vessel ''Jascon 25'' equipped with an 800-tonne crane was mobilised for the salvage operations. This work was expected to take about three months and involve cleaning and removal of debris from the rig as well as the cantilever drill floor which was left extended over the WHP helideck after the fire in November 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bairdmaritime.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7992:jascon-25-arrives-in-australia-to-remove-west-atlas&catid=70&Itemid=62|title=‘Jascon 25’ arrives in Australia to remove ‘West Atlas’|author=Tristan Tremschnig|publisher=|accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref> After the debris removal work was completed, this was followed by the jacking down of the West Atlas rig to be towed to Singapore.<ref>Peter Ker (29 September 2010). [http://www.theage.com.au/national/plan-to-tow-oil-rig-to-singapore-20100928-15vvz.html Plan to tow oil rig to Singapore]. The Age. Fairfax Media. Retrieved 18 March 2012.</ref>
PTTEPAA announced a major transformation of its Australian drilling operations on 24 November 2010 following the release of the Australian Government’s Montara Commission of Inquiry report into causes of the incident. The company said it was implementing a nine-point Action Plan to embed the highest standards of oil field practice and safety in its operations. PTTEPAA said it regretted the Montara incident and acknowledged there were deficiencies identified in the company’s operations in the Commission of Inquiry’s report. The company said drilling supervisors and management associated with the incident have been removed from their positions with the company. According to a company spokesman, the Action Plan will "ensure the full accountability of key personnel to give greater oversight for reporting and checking of all critical offshore operations. This will strengthen the integrity and safety of drilling operations".<ref name="acplim">{{cite web |url=http://www.au.pttep.com/news/2010/november/pttepaa-media-release-24-november |title=Action Plan implemented to ensure oil field safety |date=24 November 2010 |publisher=PTTEP Australasia |accessdate=18 March 2012 }}</ref>
==Initial leak and spread== [[File:West Atlas Oil Spill 1.JPG|thumb|250 px|The damaged Montara Wellhead Platform before catching fire]] [[File:West Atlas Oil Spill 3.jpg|thumb|250px|The West Atlas drilling rig and oil spill]] The leak initially emanated from the Montara Wellhead platform on 21 August 2009. The depth of water was approximately {{convert|250|ft|abbr=on|0}} and depth of hole was approximately {{convert|1.6|mi|abbr=on|0}} below the seabed.<ref name=thejakartapost /> Sixty-nine workers on the rig were safely evacuated with no injuries or fatalities.<ref name="pttep1"/> By 24 August, the oil slick resulting from the spill was estimated to be {{convert|14|km|abbr=on|0}} long and {{convert|30|m|abbr=on|-1}} wide.<ref name=ABC2 /> On 29 August, the slick was estimated at {{convert|180|km|abbr=on|-1}} at a minimum, measured east to west.<ref>{{cite news |title = Oil spill off WA coast much larger than reported: Greens |url = http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/oil-spill-off-wa-coast-much-larger-than-reported-greens-20090828-f2i7.html |work = [[WAtoday]] |date = 29 August 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3V4cSNv |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref>
By 3 September 2009, the [[Australian Maritime Safety Authority]] (AMSA) reported that the slick was {{convert|170|km|abbr=on|0}} from the coast of Western Australia, and moving closer to the shore. The slick was also reported to have spread over {{convert|6000|km2|abbr=on}} of ocean with evidence that the oil was killing marine life.<ref name=ABC3>{{cite news |title = Oil slick moving closer to coast |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/09/04/2677276.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 4 September 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3Rw9ixh |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> Reports that the slick had spread to within {{convert|120|km|abbr=on|0}} of the [[Northern Territory]] coastline were dismissed as incorrect, with the AMSA stating that the discoloured water was likely to be a natural phenomenon, such as an [[algal bloom]] or [[coral]] [[spawn (biology)|spawn]].<ref>{{cite news |title = Discoloured water 'not an oil slick' |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/09/06/2677873.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 6 September 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3S2jDp0 |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> Daily overflights by the Australian authorities in September and October 2009 identified isolated patches of weathered oil and sheen within Indonesian waters with small patches seen 94 kilometres south east of Roti Island. At the time the main spill was located about 248 kilometres from the Indonesian coastline.<ref>[http://www.indonesia.embassy.gov.au/jakt/MR09_086.html Indonesia: Montara Oil Spill - Australian Embassy]</ref>
The West Australian newspaper online reported that no oil had reached the Kimberley coastline in northern Western Australia.<ref>Michael Bennett (10 August 2010). [http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/a/-/mp/7736189/montara-oil-spill-did-not-reach-kimberley/ Montara oil spill 'did not reach Kimberley]. The West Australian. Retrieved 18 March 2012.</ref> The report was based on a West Australian Environmental Protection Authority study conducted in October 2009 during the spill. The study, released in July 2010 stated no traces of hydrocarbons were found in water or shoreline sediments in areas sampled between Camden Sound and the Stewart Islands.<ref>K.W. McAlpine, C.B. Sim, R.J. Masini and T. Daly. [http://www.epa.wa.gov.au/docs/3241_MTR3July2010-EPA.pdf Baseline petroleum hydrocarbon content of marine water, shoreline sediment and intertidal biota at selected sites in the Kimberley bioregion, Western Australia]. Office of the Environmental Protection Authority. July 2010. Retrieved 18 March 2012.</ref>
==Clean-up and response== The [[Australian Marine Oil Spill Centre]] began mobilising aircraft and equipment on 21 August 2009.<ref name=ABC4/> On 23 August 2009, a [[C-130 Hercules|Hercules]] aircraft sprayed 10,000 litres of chemical [[dispersant]] onto parts of the slick, with ongoing aerial spraying with dispersants being the primary early response to the spill.<ref name=ABC3/><ref name=ABC1/> Spraying from vessels commenced on 30 August and continued until 1 November utilising 118,000 litres of dispersant. Six different chemical dispersants were used: Slickgone NS, Slickgone LTSW, Ardrox 6120, Tergo R40, [[Corexit 9500]] and [[Corexit 9527A|Corexit 9527]]. In total, 184,135 litres<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.lawyersalliance.com.au/ourwork/montara-oil-spill|title = The Montara Oil Spill|date = |accessdate = 2014-12-07|website = Australian Lawyers Alliance|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> of chemical dispersants were sprayed from aircraft or vessels between 23 August and 1 November.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Response to the Montara Wellhead Platform Incident - Report of the Incident Analysis Team March 2010|last = |first = |publisher = Australian Maritime Safety Authority|year = 2010|isbn = |location = |pages = 4|url = http://www.amsa.gov.au/forms-and-publications/publications/montara_iat_report.pdf}}</ref>
The West Triton jackup drilling rig arrived at the Montara Field in an attempt to plug the oil leak on 11 September 2009.<ref>"[http://www.news.com.au/perthnow/story/0,27574,26059755-2761,00.html Finally, help arrives at stricken West Atlas oil rig]", The Sunday Times.</ref> Oil and gas producer, [[Woodside Petroleum]] Ltd offered to assist PTTEPAA in cleaning up the oil spill with the use of a rig closer to the spill site.<ref>{{cite news |title = Woodside offers oil spill assistance |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/08/25/2666168.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 25 August 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3SIQu0e |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> However, PTTEPAA rejected the Woodside offer on the basis of "safety reasons".<ref name=ABC5>{{cite news |title = Oil spill company rejects Woodside offer |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/08/30/2670993.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 30 August 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3SLUU45 |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> The Woodside rig was a semisubmersible drilling rig and, as it floats on the sea surface, was not deemed as a suitable platform for the relief well. A jackup rig was required because it could be secured to the sea floor giving better stability and had the capacity to pump large volumes of heavy mud needed to stop the leak.<ref>[http://www.au.pttep.com/faq.asp#Q5 PTTEP Australasia]</ref> On 6 September, the plugging of the oil leak was delayed further by a broken towline to the mobile oil rig being towed in from Indonesia by PTTEPAA.<ref>{{cite news |title = WA oil spill clean-up delayed |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/09/06/2677997.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 6 September 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3SPyKMD |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> On 7 September, the Australian Federal Government announced that it was suspending the normal approval process to fast track stopping the leak at the West Atlas oil rig.<ref>{{cite news |title = Environment laws suspended to halt slicke|url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/09/07/2679036.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 7 September 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3STmRUx |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> PTTEP Australasia initially said it could be just days before the leak was brought under control, but then said that the oil leak would continue for eight weeks until they could bring in another mobile offshore rig, West Triton, to drill a hole into the leaking oil well, and pump mud in to alleviate pressure to stop the oil flow.<ref name=ABC6/><ref name=ABC1>{{cite news |title = Oil leak could continue for 8 weeks |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/08/23/2664138.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 23 August 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3SE0SZD |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref>
On 1 November 2009, the West Triton rig successfully drilled the relief well to intercept the leaking well.<ref name=PTTEPpr83>{{cite press release |title = PTTEP Australasia Timor Sea Operations – Incident Information #83 |url = http://www.au.pttep.com/uploads/MediaRelease83_01-11-09.pdf |publisher = PTTEP Australasia |date = 1 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3PRe8Lj |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> During operations to [[well kill|kill]] the leak by pumping heavy mud down the relief well, a fire broke out from the H1 well on the well head platform.<ref name=BBCfire /><ref name="inin84">{{cite web |url=http://www.au.pttep.com/news/2009/november/timor-sea-operations---incident-information-84 |title=Timor Sea Operations - Incident Information #84 |date=1 November 2009 |publisher=PTTEP Australasia |accessdate=18 March 2012 }}</ref><ref name=PTTEPpr84>{{cite press release |title = PTTEP Australasia Timor Sea Operations – Incident Information #84 |url = http://www.au.pttep.com/uploads/MediaRelease84_01-11-09.pdf |publisher = PTTEP Australasia |date = 1 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3PVszgv |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> This was expected to delay further work on resolving the spill.<ref>{{cite news |title = Oil-spewing rig off WA ablaze |first = Fran |last = Rimrod |url = http://www.smh.com.au/environment/oilspewing-rig-off-wa-ablaze-20091101-hrf0.html |newspaper = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date = 1 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3VH7Gt4 |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> All eight non-essential personnel were taken off the West Triton rig.<ref name=PTTEPpr86 />
On 1 November 2009, the fifth attempt to intercept the well succeeded.<ref name=ABCcap/> Approximately {{convert|3400|oilbbl|m3}} of heavy mud were subsequently pumped down the relief well on 3 November 2009 thereby stopping the leak and extinguishing the fire.<ref name=PTTEPpr87 /> PTTEPAA continued to pump a mixture of heavy mud and brine into the relief to maintain a stable condition before it was eventually cemented.<ref name=PTTEPpr87 /> Once the leak was [[well kill|killed]], the main fire on the Montara Wellhead platform was extinguished. Some material on the topside of the West Atlas rig remained on fire but had extinguished by 3 November 2009 as the fuel source burnt out.<ref name=ABCcap/><ref name=PTTEPpr87 /><ref name=PTTEPpr89>{{cite press release |title = PTTEP Australasia Timor Sea Operations – Incident Information #89 |url = http://www.au.pttep.com/uploads/MediaRelease89_04-11-09.pdf |publisher = PTTEP Australasia |date = 4 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3MVsjgi |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref>
In July 2010, a PTTEPAA team reboarded the well head platform to pressure test all the wells. Following a three-week operation, the company confirmed all wells were secure.<ref name="worktobe">{{cite web |url=http://www.au.pttep.com/news/2010/august-/pttepaa-media-release-20-august-2010 |title=Work to begin to remove West Atlas drilling rig from Montara wellhead platform |date=20 August 2010 |publisher=PTTEP Australasia |accessdate=18 March 2012 }}</ref>
PTTEPAA estimates that it has spent $170 million on the gas and oil leak up to 3 November 2009. The environmental clean-up cost $5.3 million.<ref>{{cite news |title = Oil spill finally stopped: company |first = Chalpat |last = Sonti |url = http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/oil-spill-finally-stopped-company-20091103-hv56.html |work = [[WAtoday]] |date = 3 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3XWP8Fi |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> Since the spill originated directly from an oil well, it is difficult to determine its total size with any precision. Estimates range from {{convert|1.2|e6USgal|m3}} to more than {{convert|9|e6USgal|m3}}, or about 4,000 tonnes to 30,000 tonnes.<ref>{{cite news |title = Transcript of Skytruth’s John Amos to Senate on Offshore Oil Drilling |url = http://thatsmycongress.com/index.php/2009/11/19/transcript-of-skytruths-john-amos-to-senate-on-offshore-oil-drilling/ |date = 19 November 2009 |accessdate = 1 May 2010 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5pPqwnVwP |archivedate = 1 May 2010}}</ref>
==Environmental effects== The Australian Government in November 2010 released the first results of an independent scientific studies conducted under the long-term environmental monitoring program being funded by PTTEPAA under an agreement with the Australian Government announced in October 2009.<ref name="pttep2">{{cite web |url=http://www.au.pttep.com/news/2010/november/pttepaa-media-release-19-november-2010-1600hrs-wst |title=Montara Environmental Monitoring Program Delivers First Findings |date=19 November 2010 |publisher=PTTEP Australasia |accessdate=18 March 2012 }}</ref> The scientific studies issued by the Australian Department of Sustainability, Environment, Water, Population and Communities (DSEWPaC) on 19 November 2010 found that no oil reached the Australian mainland or Indonesian coast and the maximum surface area of the ocean that had hydrocarbons on it on any one given day during the spill was 11,183 square kilometres.<ref name="pttep2"/> The Australian Government sought independent expert advice on the detail of the environmental monitoring program from organisations such as the Australian Institute of Marine Science, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and State and Territory agencies. Each scientific study conducted under the program is subject to a detailed review by a DSEWPaC technical advisory board. PTTEPAA will fund the comprehensive monitoring program for at least two years, with some studies expected to continue up to five years or longer if required to provide data to measure and address any longer-term impacts should they occur. A PTTEPAA spokesperson said "the commitment to run some of the studies beyond two years does not necessarily indicate long-term impacts but supports the recommendations of independent experts to ensure the best science is in place to monitor the marine environment". The spokesperson said the studies are creating a body of high quality scientific baseline data in key areas of the Timor Sea marine environment which will be an asset for the industry and the community in managing activities in the region.<ref name="pttep2"/> [[File:Whale and calf near oil slick.JPG|thumb|250px|A whale and calf swimming near the site of the Montara oil spill]] Biologists said that the effects of the Montara oil spill could be catastrophic for [[marine ecosystems]], with claims that although it is a lightweight [[crude oil]] spilling from the platform, it can still have toxic effects on birds, [[marine invertebrates]], [[coral]] and [[marine algae]].<ref name=Buckeridge/> [[The Wilderness Society (Australia)|The Wilderness Society]] described the area as a "marine superhighway", and [[whales]] and endangered [[flatback turtle]]s observed in the area are at risk from the spill.<ref>{{cite news |title = Oil slick endangers whales, turtles |first = Narelle |last = Towie |url = http://www.news.com.au/perthnow/story/0,21598,25998853-5017007,00.html |work = [[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|PerthNow]] |date = 29 August 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3XjUVKg |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> By 3 September 2009, fishers observed sick and dying marine life, and an absence of birds in the spill area.<ref name=ABC3/> The [[World Wildlife Fund]] (WWF) observed [[spinner dolphin]]s, [[sooty tern]]s, [[Hydrophis ornatus|spotted sea snake]] and threatened [[hawksbill turtle|hawksbill]] and [[flatback turtle]]s swimming in the oil slick, and expressed concern about long-term effects. WWF also observed a wax-like residue from the oil spill.<ref name=WWF1/><ref>{{cite news |title = Dolphins exposed to Timor Sea oil spill: WWF |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/09/28/2697924.htm |work = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date = 28 September 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3SZbUjV |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> The Australian government has acknowledged treating a small number of birds as a result of the spill, including [[Brown Noddy|common noddies]], [[Brown Booby|brown boobies]] and a [[sooty tern]].<ref>{{cite web|title = Montara oil spill |url = http://www.environment.gov.au/coasts/oilspill.html |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3Y4jHxb |publisher = [[Department of the Environment, Water, Heritage and the Arts]] |archivedate = 5 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref>
=== West Timor, Indonesia === Indonesian fishermen have claimed that the spill and response polluted their national waters, killed thousands of fish and caused skin diseases<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-07-15/indonesian-fishermen-want-montara-oil-spill-investigation/5598650|title = Indonesian fishermen want Montara oil spill investigated|last = James|first = Felicity|date = 2014-07-15|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-06|last2 = Brann|first2 = Matt|publisher = ABC}}</ref> and loss of human life. [[Non-governmental organization|NGOs]] in [[Indonesia]] expressed concern about the oil spill's effects on the Indonesian environment and traditional fishing grounds as the oil spill drifted towards the islands of [[Timor]] and [[Sumba]]. The Montara oil field is situated south of Indonesia's Pasir Island, a popular fishing location for many [[East Nusa Tenggara]] fishermen.
The extent of the spread of the oil slick and sheen into Indonesian waters is disputed. Maps obtained by the [[Australian Lawyers Alliance]] under the Freedom of Information Act suggested that oil could have come as close as 37 km to the southern coast of Rote. The [[Australian Maritime Safety Authority]] advised that while figures on the maps were accurate, the maps were not drawn to scale so distances could not be visually interpreted. PTTEP maintains that the slick remained 94 km distant from Indonesia and was primarily contained within a 23 km radius of the drilling platform.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url = http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/breaking-news/secret-maps-shed-light-on-montara-spill/story-fni0xqlk-1227100481587?nk=cda22362a15a4871829a3d1e9a82f811|title = Montara maps push case for more study|last = Dunlevy|first = Gabrielle|date = 2014-10-24|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-07}}</ref>
In October 2010, fishermen claimed to have observed dramatic declines in the number of [[red snapper (fish)|red snapper]] caught by Indonesians, with 7,000 fishers impacted by loss of income,<ref>{{cite news |title = Indonesia hit by Timor Sea spill: NGO |url = http://news.theage.com.au/breaking-news-world/indonesia-hit-by-timor-sea-spill-ngo-20091102-htc1.html |agency = [[Agence France-Presse]] |newspaper = [[The Age]] |date = 2 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l3Yc7oS6 |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> including cases of bankruptcy.<ref>{{cite news |title = Oil spill sends fishermen bankrupt |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/11/07/2736012.htm?site=news |agency = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date = 2 November 2009 |accessdate = 6 November 2009}}</ref> Declining fish catches have forced thousands of fishermen to find new livelihoods on other islands as distant as the [[Bangka–Belitung Islands]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Timor Sea Oil Spill Forcing NTT Fishermen to Migrate | url = http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/home/timor-sea-oil-spill-forcing-ntt-fishermen-to-migrate/382331 | work = [[Jakarta Globe]] | agency = [[Antara (news agency)|Antara]] | date = 24 June 2010 | accessdate = 24 June 2010}}</ref> On 10 November, video emerged of Indonesian fisherman and scuba divers holding dead fish whilst in the water amongst the oil slick. The footage was allegedly taken whilst in Indonesian waters.<ref>{{cite news |title = Video could prove oil reached Timor coast |url = http://www.news.com.au/perthnow/story/0,21598,26331708-950,00.html |publisher = The Sunday Times |accessdate = 10 November 2009 | date=10 November 2009}}</ref>
The [[West Timor Care Foundation]] received reports on the death of eight people and 30 poisonous cases after the consumption of fish in the waters around areas allegedly contaminated by oil and chemical dispersant. As of October 2010, the foundation was the only Indonesian NGO to file a legal action with the Australian independent investigation commission into the Montara spill.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.antaranews.com/en/news/1288540844/australia-contaminates-indonesia-sea-with-toxic-chemicals|title = Australia contaminates Indonesia sea with toxic chemicals|last = |first = |date = 2010-10-31|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-06|publisher = Antara News}}</ref>
The Australian Lawyers Alliance has argued that in absence of sub-surface sampling of oil and chemical disperant, the spread of contamination and the environmental consequences of the spill can not be fully understood. The organisation has called for further investigation, suggesting that if Australian livelihoods had been affected there would be public outrage.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-08-21/montara-oil-spill/5685842|title = Montara oil spill: Fishermen's lawyer calls for investigation into reports of skin disease|last = James|first = Felicity|date = 2014-08-21|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-07|publisher = ABC}}</ref>
East Nusa Tenggara governor Frans Leburaya said Australia and the operator of the oil field should be held responsible for any environmental damage caused by the oil spill.<ref name="thejakartapost">{{cite news |title = Oil spill pollutes Timor Sea, nears Indonesian waters |first = Yemris |last = Fointuna |url = http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2009/09/29/oil-spill-pollutes-timor-sea-nears-indonesian-waters.html |newspaper = [[The Jakarta Post]] |date = 29 September 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> In June 2010, the East Nusa Tenggara provincial government estimated that economic losses due to the pollution of the Timor Sea resulting from the Montara spill amounted to more than 2.5-3 trillion rupiah (Rp) or $318–382 million (AUD). The loss was born exclusively by the fishermen and coastal residents whose living was dependent on marine resources.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://wikileaks.org/gifiles/docs/80/801032_idn-indonesia-asia-pacific-.html|title = The Global Intelligence Files - IDN/INDONESIA/ASIA PACIFIC|date = 2010-06-15|accessdate = 2014-12-07|website = Wikileaks|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
The Indonesian president, [[Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono]] announced that the Indonesian government would seek compensation from PTTEPAA because he believed the lives of Indonesian seaweed farmers and fishermen had been affected by the oil spill.<ref>{{cite news |title = Indonesia seeks Montara leak compensation |url = http://www.upi.com/Science_News/Resource-Wars/2010/07/22/Indonesia-seeks-Montara-leak-compensation/UPI-68571279821576/ |agency = [[United Press International]] |date = 22 July 2010}}</ref>
PTTEP Australia has stated that independent studies published by the Australian Department for the Environment found that 98.6 per cent of Montara oil stayed in Australian waters, and that the company has received "no credible evidence of damage to the environment in West Timor."<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
=== East Timor === [[East Timor]]ese President, Dr [[José Ramos-Horta]], said that the Australian government and the Thai company that own the platform are responsible for the spill, and that he will seek compensation for damage caused by the spill to his country's environment. Ramos-Horta called for Australian environmental organisations to help assess whether the spill has caused damage to East Timor's maritime area.<ref>{{cite news |title = East Timor wants compo for oil spill fallout |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/11/05/2734579.htm |agency = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date = 5 November 2009}}</ref>
==Wildlife impact monitoring== To assist in planning and executing the spill response, the Australian Government commenced an environmental monitoring program comprising a series of operational studies, including a wildlife monitoring program.<ref name="opmost">{{cite web|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/coasts/oilspill/operational-monitoring.html|title=Montara Oil spill - Operational monitoring studies|publisher=|accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref> The wildlife monitoring program sought to locate, assess and treat oil affected wildlife found in the region of the spill. Carcasses of oil affected wildlife were retained and tested to determine their cause of death. Studies undertaken under this program by Associate Professor Marthe Monique Gagnon and Dr Christopher Rawson from Curtin University in Western Australia, involved testing of four fish specimens collected in the vicinity of the spill. Tests were also conducted on 16 birds, two sea snakes and one green turtle collected in the region of the oil spill. Results announced in November 2010 found that two of the birds (both common noddies) had been affected by oil, one internally and the second both internally and externally. The study also found that the 14 remaining birds had no traces of oil. The poor physical condition of the remaining birds suggests that they likely died of natural causes. Tests on the horned sea snake indicated it had been affected by oil; however, positive hydrocarbon readings were only detected in its stomach contents. This suggests the sea snake was indirectly exposed to oil through ingesting prey. Tests on the sea turtle found no positive results for hydrocarbons, which indicated oil exposure was not the cause of death.<ref name="opmost"/>
'''Shoreline ecological assessment – Study S2''' This independent study, led by Dr Norm Duke of the University of Queensland, aimed to collect baseline information on habitats and species found along Australia’s north-west coast between Broome in Western Australia and Darwin in the Northern Territory.<ref>[http://www.environment.gov.au/coasts/oilspill.html Montara Oil spill] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5l3Y4jHxb?url=http://www.environment.gov.au/coasts/oilspill.html |date=5 November 2009 }}</ref> During November 2009, aerial surveys were undertaken covering more than 5,000 km of shoreline. The study findings are consistent with those released in July 2010 by the Environmental Protection Authority of Western Australia (EPA) from an independent survey of the Kimberley shoreline conducted in October–November 2009 which found no oil issued during the Montara incident reached the Western Australian coast.<ref name="autogenerated1">http://edit.epa.wa.gov.au/EPADocLib/MTR3-2010-Kimberley%20BL%20Hydrocarbons.pdf</ref> The EPA surveyed 16 Kimberley island shorelines and two mainland promontories between Camden Sound and the Stewart Islands. The EPA found that no hydrocarbons were detected in any water or shoreline samples and analyses of rock oyster and cultured pearl oyster show no evidence of in situ contamination.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''Oil Fate and Effects Assessment - Trajectory Analysis Study S7.1''' This study was undertaken by Asia-Pacific ASA, an Australian company that specialises in modelling, mapping and assessing spill events throughout the world.<ref>[http://www.asascience.com/services/oil-gas/index.shtml ASA | Applied Science Associates :: Oil and Gas Services]</ref> Headed by senior oceanographer Dr Brian King and senior chemist and environmental scientist Trevor Gilbert, the S7.1 study combined sightings of oil with modelling data to produce a picture of the likely extent of the spill. The results of this study will be used so that future scientific monitoring covers appropriate areas. This study used trajectory modelling, overflight data and satellite images to gain an almost hourly understanding of the spill. This study reported, in part, that no oil reached the Australian mainland or Indonesian coast. The greatest occurrence of oil was within 22.8 kilometres of the release site. Beyond 22.8 kilometres, the hydrocarbons were predominantly sheens/waxy films and of short duration. 98.6 per cent of occurrences of hydrocarbons on surface were within Australian waters.<ref name="pttep2"/> King’s oil fate and effects studies also used reports from the World Wildlife Fund (WWF), all submissions made to the Montara Commission of Inquiry and related transcripts, as well as Australian and Indonesian media reports of oil locations. Combination of all these datasets with scientific modelling ensured the most accurate and objective description of the movement of hydrocarbons in the Timor Sea throughout the incident, Dr King said. Satellite imagery used in Asia-Pacific ASA’s assessments were the same used by the WWF and oil spill tracker Skytruth, with additional high resolution imagery from LANDSAT. These combined techniques gave Dr King the highest degree of confidence in providing detailed modelling, analysis and mapping of the spill event.<ref name="pttep3">http://www.au.pttep.com/uploads/APASA%20Media%20Release%2025112010.pdf</ref>
'''Oil Fate and Effects Assessment - Dispersant Oil Modelling Study S7.2''' After using chemical dispersants to accelerate the natural breakdown of oil during the Montara incident, the Australian Government sought to find out the fate of the dispersed oil once it was in the water column. This study aimed to determine the potential concentrations of dispersed oil under the water surface using computer modelling.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/coasts/oilspill.html#monitoringstudies|title=Montara Oil spill|publisher=|accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref>
The S7.2 study undertaken by specialist company ASA-Pacific reported, in part the chemical dispersant application caused increased hydrocarbon concentrations in the water column, mostly within the first metre of the water column. However, these concentrations reduced quickly with time, depth and distance from the dispersant application site and no dispersed oil reached the Australian mainland or Indonesian coast.<ref name="pttep2"/>
The study found that under the worst-case scenario dispersed oil from three of the spraying operations may have reached the Goerree and Barracouta shoals. Because of these findings, a further study—the Scientific Monitoring Study 5 Offshore Banks Assessment Survey—will be undertaken.<ref name="environment1">{{cite web|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/coasts/oilspill/scientific-monitoring.html|title=Montara Oil spill - Scientific Monitoring Studies|publisher=|accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref> Dispersant Study S7.2 research relied on the Australian Maritime Safety Authority’s field monitoring of dispersed oil concentrations to validate S7.2 modelling. Where field data was unavailable, Asia-Pacific ASA took a "conservative approach" to modelling was taken and potential dispersed oil concentrations were overestimated to ensure further investigation by independent field monitoring teams from Western Australian Department of Fisheries and the Australian Institute of Marine Science.<ref name="pttep3"/>
'''Further studies''' The scientific studies triggered under the Montara Long Term Environmental Monitoring Program comprise: Shoreline Ecological Assessment Aerial Surveys (study S2); Assessments of Fish Catch for the Presence of Oil (study S3); Assessments of Effects on Timor Sea Fish and Fisheries (study S4); Offshore Banks Assessment Surveys (study S5); Shoreline Ecological Ground Surveys (study S6); and Oil Fate and Effects Assessments (study S7). Marine Megafauna Aerial Assessment Surveys (study S1) has not been triggered.<ref name="environment1"/>
The Australian Government released the initial scientific reports S7 and S2 in November 2010 and further studies are expected to be released in the near future.<ref name="pttep2"/>
==Cause and investigation== PTTEPAA stated shortly after the leak was plugged that they had a theory about the cause of the leak but would not disclose nor confirm the cause until they had access to the Montara Wellhead Platform and could present a thorough appraisal.<ref>"[http://www.skynews.com.au/eco/article.aspx?id=390331 Govt pledges oil leak inquiry.]"{{Failed verification|date=November 2009}}</ref>
On 5 November 2009, a [[Commission of Inquiry]] into the oil leak was announced. The inquiry, led by David Borthwick, had nearly all the powers of a [[Royal Commission]].<ref>[http://www.montarainquiry.gov.au/index.html Montara Inquiry - Home]</ref> The report was to be presented by the end of April 2010;<ref>{{cite news |title = David Borthwick to head oil spill inquiry |url = http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,26308660-26103,00.html |agency = [[Australian Associated Press]] |newspaper = [[The Australian]] |date = 5 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l34Q9yQ6 |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |title = Minister Announces Details of Montara Commission of Inquiry |url = http://minister.ret.gov.au/TheHonMartinFergusonMP/Pages/MINISTERANNOUNCESDETAILSOFMONTARACOMMISSIONOFINQUIRY.aspx |publisher = The Hon Martin Ferguson AM MP |date = 5 November 2009 |accessdate = 5 November 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5l34ZhVsZ |archivedate = 5 November 2009 }}</ref> the commission delayed their report, however, until 18 June to further examine the causes and effects of the spill.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wwf.panda.org/wwf_news/?193129/As-US-oil-spill-worsens-Australia-delays-report |title=As US oil spill worsens, Australia delays report |publisher=[[World Wide Fund for Nature]] |date=5 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/03/us/03montara.html?src=mv |title=Relief Well Was Used to Halt Australian Spill |publisher=New York Times |author=Bradsher, Keith |date=2 May 2010}}</ref>
Since the spill in August 2009 Martin Ferguson has signed 120 new gas and oil exploration licenses but has still not imposed any regulations on deep sea oil drilling.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}}
Elmer Danenberger, who used to be in charge of regulatory affairs for the U.S. Minerals Management Service, claimed that Halliburton had done a poor job [[cementing equipment|cementing]], a process that is supposed to fill the gaps around the [[Casing (borehole)|casing]] with cement to prevent leaks of oil and gas, probably causing the spill.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703572504575214593564769072|title=Drilling Process Attracts Scrutiny in Rig Explosion|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=30 April 2010|first1 = Russell |last1 = Gold | first2 = Ben |last2 =Casselman}}</ref> On 24 November 2010, Australian Resources and Energy Minister Martin Ferguson released the Report of the Montara Commission of Inquiry and a draft response from the Australian Government. The Report contained 100 findings and 105 recommendations. The Australian Government proposed accepting 92, noting 10, and not accepting three of the Report’s recommendations. Commissioner David Borthwick’s final report stated that while the source of the blowout was largely uncontested it was most likely that hydrocarbons entered the H1 Well through its 9⅝" cemented casing shoe and flowed up the inside of its 9⅝" casing. The Inquiry found that the primary well control barrier – the 9⅝" cemented casing shoe – failed. The final report by the Commission commended the spill response efforts by PTTEPAA, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority in its role as Combat Agency and the then Department of Environment, Water, Heritage and the Arts for its role as environmental regulator.<ref>http://www.ret.gov.au/Department/Documents/MIR/Montara-Report.pdf</ref>
Minister Ferguson said the failure of the operator and regulator to adhere to Australia’s oil and gas regulatory regime was a key factor in the Montara incident.<ref>[http://minister.ret.gov.au/MediaCentre/MediaReleases/Pages/FinalReportoftheMontaraCommissionofInquiryReleased.aspx Final Report of the Montara Commission of Inquiry Released]</ref>
==Legal action and resolutions== Representatives from PTTEPAA held meetings with Indonesian government officials in Perth Western Australia on 27 July and 26 August 2010, to discuss the Indonesian government’s claim for compensation.<ref name="meovin">{{cite web |url=http://www.au.pttep.com/news/2010/august-/pttepaa-media-release-26-august-2010 |title=Meeting over Indonesian oil impact claims |date=26 August 2010 |publisher=PTTEP Australasia |accessdate=18 March 2012 }}</ref> On 2 September 2010, PTTEPAA stated it did not accept any claim because no verifiable scientific evidence had been presented to the company to support the summary of claims presented by the Indonesian government.<ref name="pdna">{{cite web |url=http://www.au.pttep.com/news/2010/september/pttepaa-media-release-2-september-2010 |title=PTTEPAA does not accept compensation claim |date=2 September 2010 |publisher=PTTEP Australasia |accessdate=18 March 2012 }}</ref> In October 2010, PTTEPAA announced its commitment to the Australian Government to fund a range of scientific studies aimed at determining any environmental impacts from the incident.<ref name="bema">{{cite web |url=http://www.au.pttep.com/news/2009/september/backgrounder-%E2%80%93-environmental-monitoring-action |title=Backgrounder – Environmental Monitoring Action |date=12 September 2009 |publisher=PTTEP Australasia |accessdate=18 March 2012 }}</ref> The Commission during its inquiry took into account measures which could have been implemented to mitigate environmental damage.<ref>http://www.montarainquiry.gov.au/downloads/Commission%20of%20Inquiry_ToR.pdf</ref>
In February 2011 PTT Exploration & Production Pcl (PTTEP) was cleared to keep operating in Australian waters after satisfying the Australian government that it had taken steps to prevent a repeat of the Montara blowout.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://wikileaks.org/gifiles/docs/29/2960370_-os-australia-energy-conocophillips-outlines-proposal-for.html|title = The Global Intelligence Files - [OS] AUSTRALIA/ENERGY - ConocoPhillips Outlines Proposal for Exploration Drilling Off Australia|date = 2011-05-17|accessdate = 2014-12-07|website = Wikileaks|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
In 2012, PTTEP Australasia pleaded guilty to charges under the ''Offshore Petroleum and Greenhouse Gas Storage Act'' and was fined $510,000.<ref name=":0" />
As of 2014, the fishermen of West Timor are represented by lawyer Greg Phelps with the support of the Indonesian government. Phelps believes an independent investigation into the oil spill's environmental and economic impact in Indonesia is necessary.<ref name=":0" />
In August 2016, a class action suit was filed in Sydney, Australia representing the interests of over 13,000 Indonesian seaweed farmers whose livelihoods were affected by the spill and subsequent clean-up activities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/08/03/indonesian-farmers-file-class-action-suit-against-montara-over-2009-oil-spill.html|title=Indonesian farmers file class-action suit against Montara over 2009 oil spill|last=Gunawan Sulistiyono|first=Arif|date=2016-08-03|website=|publisher=The Jakarta Post|access-date=2016-08-04}}</ref>

{{Disputed|date=March 2015}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''N''-Acylamides}} [[File:N-acyl amide 2.tif|thumbnail]]
'''N-acyl amides''' are a general class of endogenous fatty acid compounds characterized by a fatty acyl group linked to a primary amine metabolite by an amide bond. Broadly speaking, N-acyl amides fall into several categories: amino acid conjugates (e.g., N-arachidonoyl-glycine), neurotransmitter conjugates (e.g., N-arachidonoyl-serotonin), ethanolamine conjugates (e.g., [[anandamide]]), and taurine conjugates (e.g., N-palmitoyl-taurine). N-acyl amides have pleiotropic signaling functions in physiology, including in cardiovascular function, metabolic homeostasis, memory, cognition, pain, motor control and others.<ref name="pmid15655504">{{cite journal | vauthors = Bradshaw HB, Walker JM | title = The expanding field of cannabimimetic and related lipid mediators | journal = British Journal of Pharmacology | volume = 144 | issue = 4 | pages = 459–65 | date = February 2005 | pmid = 15655504 | pmc = 1576036 | doi = 10.1038/sj.bjp.0706093 }}</ref> Initial attention focused on N-acyl amides present in mammalian organisms, however recently lipid signaling systems consisting of N-acyl amides have also been found to be present in invertebrates, such as Drosophila melanogaster.<ref name="Tortoriello">{{cite journal | vauthors = Tortoriello G, Rhodes BP, Takacs SM, Stuart JM, Basnet A, Raboune S, Widlanski TS, Doherty P, Harkany T, Bradshaw HB | title = Targeted lipidomics in Drosophila melanogaster identifies novel 2-monoacylglycerols and N-acyl amides | journal = PLOS ONE | volume = 8 | issue = 7 | pages = e67865 | date = 2013 | pmid = 23874457 | pmc = 3708943 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0067865 | bibcode = 2013PLoSO...867865T }}</ref> N-acyl amides play important roles in many biochemical pathways involved in a variety of physiological and pathological processes, as well as the metabolic enzymes, transporters, and receptors that regulate their signaling.

==Enzymatic biosynthesis and degradation==
The enzymatic biosynthesis of the N-acyl amide class of metabolites is a topic of active research with various pathways being discovered for specific N-acyl amides. For example, a proposed biosynthetic pathway for the N-acyl ethanolamines (NAEs) has been the hydrolysis of an unusual phospholipid precursor, N-acyl-phosphatidylethanolamine (NAPE), by a phospholipase D activity to liberate NAE and, as a byproduct, phosphatidic acid. Mice deficient in the enzyme NAPE-PLD show decreased in a subset of brain NAEs, providing genetic evidence for this proposal, at least for a subset of the NAEs. Other biosynthetic pathways likely exist, but the enzymes catalyzing these reactions have not yet been identified.
The degradation of NAEs in vivo is largely mediated by an enzyme called fatty acid amide hydrolase (FAAH), which catalyzes the hydrolysis of NAEs into fatty acids and ethanolamine. Mice deficient in FAAH show complete loss of NAE degradation activity in tissues and dramatic elevations in tissue levels of NAEs.
FAAH also mediates the degradation of a separate class of N-acyl amides, the N-acyl taurines (NATs). FAAH knockout mice also show dramatic increases in tissue and blood NATs. The enzymatic biosynthesis of NATs remains unknown.
A distinct circulating enzyme, peptidase M20 domain containing 1 ([[PM20D1 (gene)|PM20D1]]), can catalyze the bidirectional the condensation and hydrolysis of a variety of N-acyl amino acids in vitro. In vivo, PM20D1 overexpression increases the levels of various N-acyl amino acids in blood, demonstrating that this enzyme can contribute to N-acyl amino acid biosynthesis.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Long JZ, Svensson KJ, Bateman LA, Lin H, Kamenecka T, Lokurkar IA, Lou J, Rao RR, Chang MR, Jedrychowski MP, Paulo JA, Gygi SP, Griffin PR, Nomura DK, Spiegelman BM | title = The Secreted Enzyme PM20D1 Regulates Lipidated Amino Acid Uncouplers of Mitochondria | journal = Cell | volume = 166 | issue = 2 | pages = 424–435 | date = July 2016 | pmid = 27374330 | pmc = 4947008 | doi = 10.1016/j.cell.2016.05.071 }}</ref> PM20D1 knockout mice have complete loss of N-acyl amino acid hydrolysis activity in blood and tissues with concomitant bidirectional dysregulation of endogenous N-acyl amino acids.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal | vauthors = Long JZ, Roche AM, Berdan CA, Louie SM, Roberts AJ, Svensson KJ, Dou FY, Bateman LA, Mina AI, Deng Z, Jedrychowski MP, Lin H, Kamenecka TM, Asara JM, Griffin PR, Banks AS, Nomura DK, Spiegelman BM | title = N-acyl amino acid control of metabolism and nociception | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 115 | issue = 29 | pages = E6937–E6945 | date = July 2018 | pmid = 29967167 | pmc = 6055169 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.1803389115 }}</ref>
==Biological Activity==
N-acyl amides have been shown to play an important role in a variety of physiological functions as lipid signaling molecule. Apart from the aforementioned roles in cardiovascular function, memory, cognition, pain, and motor control, the compounds have also been shown to play a role in cell migration, inflammation and certain pathological conditions such as diabetes, cancer, neurodegenerative disease, and obesity.<ref name="Waluk" />
In a more general sense, one of the key characteristics of the N-acyl amide group of compounds is their ubiquitous nature. Research has shown the presence of the compounds in mice, ''Drosophila melanogaster, Arabidopsis, C. Elegans, Cerevisiae (yeast), Pseudomonas Syringae'', olive oil and PYD media<ref>Bradshaw, Heather B.,Leishman, Emma. “Expanding the range of potential “endogenous cannabinoids” to incorporate lipids in bacteria, yeast, worms, and flies: cannabimimetic lipids are not just from arachidonic acid anymore.” IRCS Poster Presentation. 2013.</ref> . This diverse presence of N-acyl amides attests to their importance in multiple biological systems and also shows that the detected presence of specific N-acyl amides in a number of species, including humans, may be endogenous or exogenous.
N-acyl amides are primarily involved in cell-to-cell communication in biological systems. An example of this is the lipid signaling system involving transient receptor potential channels (TRP), which interact with N-acyl amides such as N-arachidonoyl ethanolamide (Anandamide), N-arachidonoyl dopamine and others in an opportunistic fashion.<ref name="pmid23178153">{{cite journal | vauthors = Bradshaw HB, Raboune S, Hollis JL | title = Opportunistic activation of TRP receptors by endogenous lipids: exploiting lipidomics to understand TRP receptor cellular communication | journal = Life Sciences | volume = 92 | issue = 8–9 | pages = 404–9 | date = March 2013 | pmid = 23178153 | pmc = 3587287 | doi = 10.1016/j.lfs.2012.11.008 }}</ref> This signaling system has been shown to play a role in the physiological processes involved in inflammation.<ref name="pmid25136293">{{cite journal | vauthors = Raboune S, Stuart JM, Leishman E, Takacs SM, Rhodes B, Basnet A, Jameyfield E, McHugh D, Widlanski T, Bradshaw HB | title = Novel endogenous N-acyl amides activate TRPV1-4 receptors, BV-2 microglia, and are regulated in brain in an acute model of inflammation | journal = Frontiers in Cellular Neuroscience | volume = 8 | issue = | pages = 195 | date = 2014 | pmid = 25136293 | pmc = 4118021 | doi = 10.3389/fncel.2014.00195 }}</ref> Other N-acyl amides, including N-oleoyl-glutamine, have also been characterized as TRP channel antagonists.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
An application of N-acyl amides that is currently at the forefront of related research is the correlation between oleoyl serine and bone remodeling. Recent research has shown that oleoyl serine, an N-acyl amide found in olive oil amongst other sources, plays a role in the proliferation of osteoblast activity and the inhibition of osteoclast activity.<ref name="pmid20876113">{{cite journal | vauthors = Smoum R, Bar A, Tan B, Milman G, Attar-Namdar M, Ofek O, Stuart JM, Bajayo A, Tam J, Kram V, O'Dell D, Walker MJ, Bradshaw HB, Bab I, Mechoulam R | title = Oleoyl serine, an endogenous N-acyl amide, modulates bone remodeling and mass | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 107 | issue = 41 | pages = 17710–5 | date = October 2010 | pmid = 20876113 | pmc = 2955099 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0912479107 | bibcode = 2010PNAS..10717710S }}</ref> Further research regarding this application of oleoyl serine is set to take place to explore the possible correlation between the consumption of the compound by individuals at risk for osteoporosis.
Certain N-acyl amino acids can act as [[Dinitrophenol|chemical uncouplers]] and directly stimulate [[Mitochondrion|mitochondrial]] respiration. These N-acyl amino acids are characterized by medium chain, unsaturated fatty acyl chains and neutral amino acid head groups.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Lin H, Long JZ, Roche AM, Svensson KJ, Dou FY, Chang MR, Strutzenberg T, Ruiz C, Cameron MD, Novick SJ, Berdan CA, Louie SM, Nomura DK, Spiegelman BM, Griffin PR, Kamenecka TM | title = Discovery of Hydrolysis-Resistant Isoindoline N-Acyl Amino Acid Analogues that Stimulate Mitochondrial Respiration | journal = Journal of Medicinal Chemistry | volume = 61 | issue = 7 | pages = 3224–3230 | date = April 2018 | pmid = 29533650 | doi = 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.8b00029 }}</ref> Administration of these N-acyl amino acids to mice elevates energy expenditure leading to profound body weight loss and improvement of glucose homeostasis.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Long JZ, Svensson KJ, Bateman LA, Lin H, Kamenecka T, Lokurkar IA, Lou J, Rao RR, Chang MR, Jedrychowski MP, Paulo JA, Gygi SP, Griffin PR, Nomura DK, Spiegelman BM | display-authors = 6 | title = The Secreted Enzyme PM20D1 Regulates Lipidated Amino Acid Uncouplers of Mitochondria | journal = Cell | volume = 166 | issue = 2 | pages = 424–435 | date = July 2016 | pmid = 27374330 | pmc = 4947008 | doi = 10.1016/j.cell.2016.05.071 }}</ref>
Overall, the applications of N-acyl amides in biological settings are abundant. As mentioned, their importance in cell signaling in a variety systems leading to various physiological roles and in turn therapeutic capabilities, which gives all the more reason to continue the extensive research being conducted on the compounds today.
Several N-acyl amides have been demonstrated to physiologically activate G-protein coupled receptors. Anandamide activates the cannabinoid receptors CB1 and CB2. FAAH knockout mice show increased anandamide levels in vivo and cannabinoid-receptor dependent behaviors including antinociception and anxiolysis. GPR18, GPR55, GPR92 have also been proposed to be activated by various N-acyl amides, though the physiological relevance of these assignments remains unknown.

FilmCritic.com. | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Oil on Ice''''' is a 2004 documentary film directed by Bo Boudart and Dale Djerassi. It explores the [[Arctic Refuge drilling controversy]] in the [[Arctic National Wildlife Refuge]] (ANWR) and the impact of oil and gas development on the land, wildlife, and lives of the [[Gwich'in people|Gwich'in]] Athabascan Indians and [[Inupiat people|Inupiat Eskimos]].McNary, Dave (November 18, 2004). [http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117913777?refcatid=1742&printerfriendly=true "'Fahrenheit,' 'Born' share top IDA kudos"]. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''. ==Cast== The film was narrated by [[Peter Coyote]] and features interviews with and footage of [[environmentalists]] [[Amory Lovins]], [[Celia Hunter]], [[Sarah James]], [[Norma Kassi]], former Alaska Governor [[Tony Knowles (politician)|Tony Knowles]], former Alaska Senator [[Ted Stevens]], California Senator [[Barbara Boxer]], former [[Sierra Club]] director [[Carl Pope (environmentalist)|Carl Pope]], Ken Whitten, David Klein, former [[Fairbanks North Star Borough]] Mayor [[Jim Whitaker]], former [[North Slope Borough]] Mayor George N. Ahmaogak, and Inupiaq activist and former [[Nuiqsut]] mayor Rosemary Ahtuangaruak. ==Production== ''Oil on Ice'' was sponsored by Northern Alaska Environmental Center (NAEC) and was filmed on location in [[Alaska]], [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]], and [[Washington, DC]].Engebretson, Russell (August 25th, 2005).[http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/oilonice.php ''Oil on Ice''] review. DVDVerdict.com To promote and market the film, Steve Michelson engaged fourteen non-profit organizations, including the [[Sierra Club]], members of which hosted thousands of house parties to screen and distribute materials about the film, and to promote grassroots efforts to prevent ANWR drilling.{{cite book | title=Shooting in the Wild: An Insider's Account of Making Movies in the Animal Kingdom|page= 24 | first=Chris |last=Palmer |year= 2010 |publisher=Sierra Club Books|isbn= 978-1578051489 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Op2Jb6xopDgC&pg=PA24#v=onepage&f=false}} ===Release=== The film premiered at [[Mountainfilm in Telluride]] on May 31, 2004, and was released on DVD September 6, 2005. The soundtrack CD ''[[Oil on Ice (soundtrack)|Oil on Ice]]'' by [[William Susman]], featuring cellist [[Joan Jeanrenaud]], was released on October 16, 2007. ==Reception== FilmCritic.com reviewer Eric Meyerson described the film as "unabashed counter-propaganda to the pro-drilling forces" seeking access to wilderness land. He credits its professional production and its "powerful story, with astonishing wildlife photography and fascinating and tragic tales of the plights of local fishermen and native tribes." Meyerson found the interviews with Gwich'in Indian Adeline Peter Raboff "particularly affecting." He noted that the film is "as one-sided as the ''[[O'Reilly Factor]]''" in that it "failed to address any positive economic impacts that the oil industry has had on Alaskans." But he termed the film "well-made counter-propaganda. If anything, ''Oil on Ice'' is worth seeing just to see exactly what ExxonMobil and CononoPhillips are getting ready to tear into." Russell Engebretson, writing for DVDVerdict, wrote of its "beautiful Alaskan wildlife cinematography, including one truly stunning shot of a grazing [[Caribou]] herd that must have numbered in the thousands. For contrast, we get an aerial view of the massive, grotesque [[Prudhoe Bay]] drilling operation that abuts ANWR to the west." He noted that while the "wilderness scenery is delightful, there is ample interview material as well." Of the many interviewees, he found that two, Pope and Levin, "drag down the film", and that Levin "steers the film away from its central thesis — the exploitation of ANWR." Engebretson felt that the documentary erred in two ways: "by lionizing people who don't deserve such treatment", and "in presenting [John] Kerry as a foe of Big Oil". Summarizing, he found the film to be "a good, basic introduction (from an anti-drilling point-of-view) to the oil extraction debate." ==Awards== ''Oil on Ice'' received several awards: the 2004 [[International Documentary Association]] ''Pare Lorentz Award'' for best representing the "democratic sensibility, activist spirit and lyrical vision" of [[Pare Lorentz]], the 2005 Missoula [[International Wildlife Film Festival]] ''Festival Prize'',{{cite web |title=2005 Award Winners |publisher=[[International Wildlife Film Festival]] |url=http://www.wildlifefilms.org/festival/awards_cf.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050411014827/http://www.wildlifefilms.org/festival/awards_cf.htm |archivedate=2005-04-11 |accessdate=2011-05-19}} the 2005 [[Moondance International Film Festival]] ''Calypso Award'' for feature documentary and ''Seahorse Award'' for best film score,{{cite web |title=Congratulations Moondance 2005 Winners |publisher=Moondance Film Festival |url=http://www.moondancefilmfestival.com/05-Winners.html | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060326043358/http://www.moondancefilmfestival.com/05-Winners.html |archivedate=2006-03-26 |accessdate=2011-05-19}} and the 2006 Park City Film Music Festival ''Gold Medal for Excellence'' in the category Documentary, Jury Choice: Best Impact of Music.[http://www.pcfmf.com/past.html Past Festivals].
